content.description: You can see this line from town! It's the splitter crack of splitter cracks, but the catch is that you have to climb bouldery steepness (bolt, consider stick clipping it) and a runout face bit (5.5 R/X) to access said splitter. But oh how splitter it is! The splitter crack also runs out before the top, and you have to do 5.9 slab moves (bolt) to get to the anchors. So this amazing (!) splitter requires that you climb a bouldery start, a runout, and a slab finish. Welcome to Waterville, where things are never quite what they seem.
content.location: Left side of the cliff. Splitter crack in a bone-white slab.

content.description: The all bolted line right up the middle of the wall of corners. Look for the irresistible huecos. Climb up onto a pedestal, past a cruxy move that will be nice if it ever dries out. stay right of the bolts in the corner until eventually having to break left through a steep exit. Fun climbing it just cant seem to shake the wetness. If it's dry, DO IT!
content.location: Look for the huecos in the middle of the wall of corners. The only fully bolted route in this section.

content.description: A subtle yet eye-catching feature tucked away on the far right end. Locate the line by spotting the rounded arete just beyond the inside corner of Swordfighter. The crux happens right off the ground so definitely stick clip the first bolt. Tackle a sequence of strenuous moves on indistinct holds that would seem more at home on a boulder. Perhaps a V4 intro.  From a stance move up on more reasonable ground, perhaps stout 5.10 from here to the top. Excellent climbing the whole way!It is possible to sneak around the Crux start by starting a good bit to the right and walking a ledge back left. This keeps the route in the 5.10 range.
content.location: On the far right end of the cliff past the obvious inside corner of Swordfighter look for a rounded arete a little like Lonesome dove. That's the rig.

content.description: Arguably the best sport route in the Waterville region, this pitch is definitely worth the hike. It climbs up a left-facing corner on perfect rock through multiple cruxes, a few rests, and a heartbreaking sting-in-the-tail final mantle finish just below the anchors.
content.location: Right side of the main wall.

content.description: After Bovine Song saw its FA, the rest of the barnyard wanted some attention. Start up a vertical wall to a tricky mantle, gain some easier terrain and mantle again. After mantle number two, enjoy 5.7ish climbing above the trees on beautiful rock to the top of the cliff. The anchors are a bit high, so bring some long runners for your shorter climbing partners.
content.location: Just after the Wall of Corners you’ll see an obvious crack leading to the mantle, with a good ledge for your feet. This is where the Party starts.

content.description: This is the groove on the right side of the cliff, just left of a big popcorn roof. Start with difficulty up a groove until you can exit the groove to the left. Move up to a stance under the upper overhang. Crank the overhang (crux) to a wider crack and bolted anchors to the left. With better rock this would be a 3 star route, but alas, the rock just isn't great, especially at the start and the end.
content.protection: Gear--thin to wide. Bolted lower offs.

content.description: This route climbs a line of bolts up beautiful rock right of Waterville Crack to a nice splitter. The catch is that turning the lip at the second bolt requires a holdless mantle that feels quite hard. Even so, a quick yank on the bolt allows this route to go at 5.11 A0, and is still a worthwhile outing.
content.protection: Draws and a couple of pieces of gear.
content.location: Left side of cliff, just right of Waterville Crack. Finishes as per Waterville Crack.

content.description: The most demanding of the corner routes, this climbs the corner just right of Add it Up. Clip a bolt, then move into the crux finger crack where you have to decide if you want gear or handholds--cause you can't have both. Top out on a ledge, and then work up steeper rock with bolts to a long finish on a slab. The anchors are high on the cliff.
content.protection: Bolt to gear (fingers to thin-hands) to bolts to bolted lower off.
content.location: Right side of Wall of Corners. Just left of Rooster Party

content.description: This is a stellar adventure and though it might not seem perfect as you start up on slightly Crumbly rock... It Gets Better! Stick Clip the first bolt. Climb bouldery terrain heading toward that sweet corner crack. layback and jam and make a funky move to get up onto the slab. Continue up the slab jamming. Break up through a groove and embark on 3 bolts of thought provoking friction. The crux has proven to be the last couple of moves of pure friction. The rollercoaster of emotions will all be worth it when you look out from the anchor at the breathtaking view. An amazing place to be climbing.
content.protection: 4(?) bolts, trad gear, to ring anchors
content.location: Between the monster flake and what I call the wall of corners, look for a left facing corner about 15 feet off the ground. That's the spot.

climbs.name: The Hansche/Knower
climbs.fa: Lee Hansche and jay Knower, Summer 2020

content.description: Perhaps one of the best hard trad testpieces in the Waterville region, this climbs a steep corner crack in the center of the cliff. Clip a bolt to get past some rotten rock at the start and cast into a tenuous layback up the steep crack. The crux is pulling the lip after which you're treated to a long and glorious series of 5.9 cracks. This is one of those climbs that you write home about.
content.protection: One bolt, gear: stoppers to #4 camalot.
content.location: Middle of the cliff. Ends at the bolted anchors for It Gets Better (just to the right)

content.description: This is the perpetually wet and perpetually mossy wide crack on the left side of the main cliff. Slither your way up, using some blocks that may or may not be loose, but most likely are wet and/or dirty. It might be charitable to say that this route offers "climbing"; it might be more accurate to call it "wriggling", "thrutching", or better yet, "oozing". It ends at bolted anchors.
content.protection: The best protection from this route would be to keep walking past it.
content.location: Left side of the cliff. It's the wide crack that leads you to say to your friend: "I can't believe anyone climbed that."

climbs.name: Friends, Lies, & The End of the World

content.description: Work your way up the slightly left leaning crack. After pulling some tricky moves in the lower corner, climb the slab and ever widening crack under the roof till it exits a lip and eases back at the anchors.
content.protection: Mixed gear. Standard rack. May want a #4 for near the top.
content.location: Right side of the cliff . Look for a short corner capped by a wide crack under a roof.

content.description: Stick clip the first bolt. Climb The gigantic flake then break right up the little V-groove past 2 more bolts. Scamper up through easier climbing protected by trad gear. Slab your way up past a few more bolts to a two bolt anchor. The crux is around the V-groove but don't fall asleep. There are a few tricks near the top.
content.protection: 6(?) bolts and a few cams to ring anchor.
content.location: Near the left end of the cliff you can't miss the monster flake. This route climbs it's right side.

content.description: On the very far right end of the wall there is a low angle face hosting a sport route with 4 bolts and an anchor. The climbing basically connects good holds and solid stances zig-zagging up to the anchor. Though this line is worth climbing and works fine as a warm up it feels like it just misses the mark. The clips are a little awkward and their placement avoids some of the cooler features on the wall. Perhaps it could have been two more direct routes rather than one that wonders a bit.
content.location: The very far right end of the main wall.

content.description: There is an unmistakable section of High Camp Cliff that I call the wall of corners. It is right in the center of the wall and there are aretes and dihedrals conspicuously side by side. The is the left most inside corner. It starts just to the right of an evergreen tree. Climb past a couple of bolts (placed because the rock looked a bit sketchy at the start). Layback and jam the rest of the way on natural gear. Careful the tree might try to grab your chalkbag in the crux ;) scoot right to the shared anchor.
content.protection: 2 bolts, trad gear, two bolt anchor.
content.location: The left most line on the wall of corners by the tree.

content.description: Climb up the line of least resistance at the very edge of the cliff. Clip the first bolt (some may want to stick clip) and make the traverse moves through to some really cool huecos. Transition into the vertical crack. Take the crack up until it disappears and work your way up some cool moderate slabbin’ and face climbing to the anchors. Cool varied movement and interesting features.
content.location: Farthest route left on the main cliff.

content.description: The name says it all: this is an offwidth that might force you into cow-like grunts. Start right of Swordfighter, below the offwidth in a big chimney, and climb about 30 feet of unprotected rock (5.6R) to a good stance where you can place gear. Work up the left-leaning offwidth until you can exit left to Swordfighter's anchors. A direct start (Bovine Wail, 5.11 PG) has been completed up the thin crack just to the left of the chimney start.
content.protection: Cams, thin hands to wide, to anchors.

content.description: The centerpiece of the Wall of Corners, right in the center of the cliff, Add it Up climbs the middle corner. It's the perfect mixed route: a bolt protects the start, then finger gear protects the splitter corner crack in the middle of the route, and two bolts protect the boulder problem exit. And it's a bit steeper than it looks. It ends on a midway ledge on the cliff at bolted anchors. Add it all up (see what I did there?) and you have a classic pitch.
content.protection: 3 bolts and finger-thin hands gear. Bolted lower off.
content.location: Center of the cliff, middle corner of the Wall of Corners.

content.description: The High Camp area sports perhaps the best high-altitude cragging in New Hampshire. Situated at about 4000 feet on the southeast slope of Mt Osceola, these cliffs are the perfect summer spot. When it's sweltering down in the lowlands, chaces are there's a nice breeze up at this crag. This is a mountain environment, so watch for mountain weather, which includes sudden and violent afternoon thunderstorms. Bring a light rack, a 60m rope, and perhaps some bigger cams. There is something for everyone here: some trad, some sport, and some mixed, from 5.5 to 5.12, and all developed in the modern idiom, which includes bolts where you need 'em, and convenient lower offs on most pitches.
